words.def: 12th man: expression used to describe fans present at a football match, especially when they make such noise as to provide increased motivation for the team.[9] The metaphor is based on the fact that a team numbers 11 active players at the start of a game. The term can also be used where a referee is perceived to be biased in favour of one team. "They had a 12th man on the pitch", is a complaint made by fans.
words.name: 12th man

words.def: 2–3–5: common 19th- and early 20th-century formation consisting of two defensive players (previously known as full backs), three midfield players (half-backs), and five forward players. Also known as the pyramid formation. Variations include the 2–3–2–3 (the Metodo or WW formation), where the inside forwards take up deeper positions.[3]
words.name: 2–3–5

words.def: 3 points for a win: see Three points for a win.
words.name: 3 points for a win

words.def: 39th game: see game 39.
words.name: 39th game

words.def: 4–4–2: common modern formation used with four defenders, four midfielders, and two attacking players. There are many variants of this formation, such as the 4–4–2 diamond, where the four midfielders are assembled in a diamond shape without wide midfielders, and the 4–1–3–2, where one midfielder is expected to adopt a defensive position, allowing the other three to concentrate on attacking.[10]
words.name: 4–4–2

words.def: 4–5–1: common modern formation used with four defenders, five midfielders and one striker. By pushing the wingers forward, this formation can be adapted into a 4–3–3; teams frequently play 4–3–3 when they have the ball, and revert to 4–5–1 when they lose possession.[11] Variants include the 4–4–1–1, where a striker drops deep or an attacking midfielder pushes forward to play in a supporting role to the main striker, the 4–2–3–1, where two holding midfielders are used, the 4–3–2–1 (or Christmas Tree), which uses three central midfielders behind two attacking midfielders[3][12] and 4-6-0 which utilizes four defenders and six midfielders deployed as one holding player, two wing-backs and three who rotate between attack and defence positions.[13]
words.name: 4–5–1

words.def: 4th place trophy: The achievement of qualifying for the UEFA Champion's League by finishing in the top four places in the English Premier League. The term was coined by Arsene Wenger, who said that "For me, there are five trophies, the first is to win the Premier League... the third is to qualify for the Champions League,".
words.name: 4th place trophy

words.def: 50-50: see fifty-fifty

6+5 rule: proposal adopted by FIFA in 2008. Designed to counter the effects of the Bosman ruling, which had greatly increased the number of foreign players fielded by European clubs, the rule required each club to field at least six players who are eligible to play for the national team of the country of the club.[14] The European Parliament prevented the rule from coming into effect in the European Union, declaring it incompatible with EU law – its future remains uncertain.[15]
words.name: 6+5 rule

words.def: Academy: model used by some professional clubs for youth development. Young players are contracted to the club and trained to a high standard, with the hope that some will develop into professional footballers.[16] Some clubs provide academic as well as footballing education at their academies.[17] Also known as a youth academy.
words.name: Academy

words.def: Added time: see Stoppage time.
words.name: Added time

words.def: Administration: legal process where a business unable to pay its creditors seeks temporary legal protection from them, while it attempts to restructure its debt. Clubs going into administration usually incur a points deduction.[18]
words.name: Administration

words.def: Advantage: decision made by the referee during a game, where a player is fouled, but play is allowed to continue because the team that suffered the foul is in a better position than they would have been had the referee stopped the game.[19]
words.name: Advantage

words.def: AFC: initialism for either the Asian Football Confederation,[20] the governing body of the sport in Asia, or association football club, used by teams such as Sunderland AFC.[21] also used for "athletic football club" for instance A.F.C. Bournemouth.
words.name: AFC

words.def: Against the run of play: describes a goal scored, or a win or draw achieved, by a side that was being clearly outplayed.[22]
words.name: Against the run of play

words.def: Aggregate or aggregate score: combined score of matches between two teams in a two-legged match.[23]
words.name: Aggregate

words.def: Anti-football: pejorative term for a particularly robust and defensive style of play.[24]
words.name: Anti-football

words.def: Apertura and Clausura: league format employed by several football leagues in Latin America, in which the traditional August–May season is divided into two separate league tournaments, each with its own champion. Apertura and Clausura are Spanish for "opening" and "closing".[25]
words.name: Apertura and Clausura

words.def: Arena football: see six-a-side football.
words.name: Arena football

words.def: Armband: worn by a team's captain, to signify that role.[26] Black armbands are occasionally worn by an entire team in commemoration of a death or tragic event.[27]
words.name: Armband

words.def: Assist: pass that leads to a goal being scored.[28]
words.name: Assist

words.def: Assistant referee: one of a number of officials who assist the referee in controlling a match.[29]
words.name: Assistant referee

words.def: Attacker: usually refers to a striker,[30] but can be used to describe any player close to the opposing team's goal line.
words.name: Attacker

words.def: Away: see Home and away.
words.name: Away

words.def: Away goals rule: tie-break applied in some competitions with two-legged matches. In cases where the scores finish level on aggregate, the team that has scored more goals away from home is deemed the winner.[23]
words.name: Away goals rule

words.def: Back-pass rule: rule introduced into the Laws of the Game in 1992 to help speed up play, specifying that goalkeepers are not allowed to pick up the ball if it was intentionally kicked back to them by a teammate.[31]
words.name: Back-pass rule

words.def: Backheel: pass between team-mates, in which one player uses their heel to propel the ball backwards to another player. Sometimes spelt back heel.[32]
words.name: Backheel

words.def: Ball: spherical object normally kicked around by football players. Balls used in official matches are standardised for size, weight, and material, and manufactured to the specifications set in the Laws of the Game.[33]
words.name: Ball

words.def: Ball boy: one of several children, male or female, stationed around the edge of the pitch, whose role is to help retrieve balls that go out of play.[34]
words.name: Ball boy

words.def: Ballon d'Or: may refer to the current FIFA Ballon d'Or, awarded to the player voted the best in world football, or a previous award, which recognised the best player in European football.[35][vague]
words.name: Ballon d'Or

words.def: Barras bravas: name used to describe organised supporter/hooligan groups in Latin America, similar to the European term Ultras.[36]
words.name: Barras bravas

words.def: Beach football: variant of association football played on a beach or some form of sand.[37] Also known as beach soccer or beasal.
words.name: Beach football

words.def: Behind closed doors: matches in which spectators are not present. May be imposed as a form of sanction for clubs whose supporters have behaved inappropriately.[38] Such matches are sometimes arranged between clubs, to help hasten a player's return to fitness.[39]
words.name: Behind closed doors

words.def: Bench: area on the edge of the pitch where a team's substitutes and coaches sit, usually consisting an actual covered bench or a row of seats. More formally known as the substitutes' bench.[40] Also sometimes called a dugout.[41]
words.name: Bench

words.def: Bend: skill attribute in which players strike the ball in a manner that applies spin, resulting in the flight of the ball curving, or bending, in mid-air. Players who are especially adept at achieving this will often be their team's designated free kick taker, as they are able to bend the ball around walls while taking shots at goal. The phrase "bend it like Beckham" stems from English player David Beckham's ability in this regard.[42]
words.name: Bend

words.def: Bicycle kick: move made by a player with their back to the goal. The player throws their body into the air, makes a shearing movement with the legs to get one leg in front of the other, and attempts to play the ball backwards over their own head, all before returning to the ground. Also known as an overhead kick.[43]
words.name: Bicycle kick

words.def: Booking: act of noting the offender in a cautionable offence, which results in a yellow card.[44]
words.name: Booking

words.def: Boot boy: young player who, in addition to his football training, is expected to perform menial tasks such as cleaning the boots of first-team players.[45]
words.name: Boot boy

words.def: Bosman ruling: ruling by the European Court of Justice related to player transfers that allows professional football players in the European Union to move freely to another club at the end of their term of contract with their present team. Handed down in 1995, it also banned the restricted movement of EU members within the leagues of member states. Named after Jean-Marc Bosman, the plaintiff in that court case.[46]
words.name: Bosman ruling

words.def: Box: see Penalty area.
words.name: Box

words.def: Box-to-box: a term used to describe players with the ability to influence the game both defensively and offensively or, more generally, at both ends of the pitch.[47]
words.name: Box-to-box

words.def: Brace: when a player scores two goals in a single match.[8]
words.name: Brace

words.def: Break: attacking manoeuvre in which several members of a defending team gain possession of the ball and suddenly counter-attack into their opponent's half of the pitch, overwhelming their opponents' defence in greater numbers, usually as a result of the opposing defenders' being out of position after having supported their attackers.[48]
words.name: Break

words.def: Bung: secret and unauthorised payment, used as a financial incentive to help a transfer go through.[49]
words.name: Bung

words.def: Byline: markings on the shortest side of the pitch, which run from the posts to the corners. Also known as the End line.[30]
words.name: Byline

words.def: CAF: initialism for the Confederation of African Football, the governing body of the sport in Africa.[20]
words.name: CAF

words.def: Cap: appearance of a player for a national team. Originates from the traditional presentation of a cap to British players who made international appearances.[50][51]
words.name: Cap

words.def: Cap-tied: a term used when a player has represented a national team and as a consequence is ineligible to play for another.
words.name: Cap-tied

words.def: Captain: player chosen to lead a team, and in a match to participate in the coin toss before the start of play.[52] Also known as a skipper.[30]
words.name: Captain

words.def: Caretaker manager: person chosen to perform managerial duties when no permanent manager is installed.[53]
words.name: Caretaker manager

words.def: Catenaccio: tactical system that puts an emphasis on defence. In Italian, catenaccio means "door-bolt", implying a highly organised and effective backline defence to prevent goals.[54]
words.name: Catenaccio

words.def: Caution: see yellow card.
words.name: Caution

words.def: Centre circle: 10-yard radius circle around the centre spot.[55]
words.name: Centre circle

words.def: Centre spot: mark in the centre of the pitch from which play is started at the beginning of each half, and restarted following the scoring of a goal.[55]
words.name: Centre spot

words.def: Challenge: see tackle.
words.name: Challenge

words.def: Channel: empty space between the fullback and the central defender when a defense is playing with a back four. Wide-playing strikers are said to operate "in the channels".[56]
words.name: Channel

words.def: Champions League: annual confederation-wide tournament involving the champions and other successful teams from that confederation's domestic leagues. The term can refer to the tournaments held in the AFC,[57] CAF,[58] CONCACAF[59] or OFC,[60] but is most commonly used in reference to the competition held by UEFA.[61] The CONMEBOL equivalent is the Copa Libertadores.[62]
words.name: Champions League

words.def: Chance: situation where an attacking player can shoot at goal, with a realistic prospect of scoring. Also known as an opportunity.[63]
words.name: Chance

words.def: Chip: high trajectory shot, hit with the intention of the ball going over the goalkeeper and into the goal.[64]
words.name: Chip

words.def: Christmas tree: see 4–5–1
words.name: Christmas tree

words.def: Clausura: see Apertura and Clausura
words.name: Clausura

words.def: Clean sheet: when a goalkeeper or team does not concede a single goal during a match.[5]
words.name: Clean sheet

words.def: Clearance: when a player kicks the ball away from the goal they are defending.[30]
words.name: Clearance

words.def: Club: collective name for a football team, and the organisation that runs it.[65]
words.name: Club

words.def: Co-ownership: system whereby two football clubs own the contract of a player jointly, although the player is only registered to play for one club.[66]
words.name: Co-ownership

words.def: CONCACAF: acronym for the Confederation of North, Central American and Caribbean Association Football, the governing body of the sport in North and Central America and the Caribbean; pronounced "kon-ka-kaff".[20]
words.name: CONCACAF

words.def: CONMEBOL: acronym for the South American Football Association, the governing body of the sport in South America; pronounced "kon-me-bol".[20]
words.name: CONMEBOL

words.def: Corner flag: flags are placed in each of the four corners of the pitch to help mark the boundaries of the playing area.[55]
words.name: Corner flag

words.def: Corner kick: kick taken from within a one-yard radius of the corner flag; a method of restarting play when a player puts the ball behind their own goal line without a goal being scored.[30]
words.name: Corner kick

words.def: Corridor of uncertainty: a cross or pass which is delivered into the area in front of the goalkeeper and behind the last line of defence.[67]
words.name: Corridor of uncertainty

words.def: Counter-attack or counterattack: see break.
words.name: Counter-attack

words.def: Cross: delivery of the ball into the penalty area by the attacking team, usually from the area between the penalty box and the touchline.[30]
words.name: Cross

words.def: Crossbar: horizontal bar across the top of the goal.[68]
words.name: Crossbar

words.def: Cruyff turn: type of turn named after Dutchman Johan Cruyff; designed to lose an opponent. Specifically, the ball is gently kicked sideways by one foot, but behind the player's own standing leg.[69]
words.name: Cruyff turn

words.def: Cuauhtemiña: skill move attributed to Mexican player Cuauhtémoc Blanco,[70] which he performed notably at the 1998 World Cup.[71] When multiple players attempted to tackle him, he trapped the ball between his feet and jumped over them, releasing the ball in the air and landing with it under control.[71]
words.name: Cuauhtemiña

words.def: Cup (~ competition, ~ format, ~ tie): a single-elimination tournament, as opposed to a league (round-robin tournament); respectively called after England's FA Cup and Football League. Depending on the competition, cup ties may be a single match or a two-legged tie; often the "cup final" is a single match at a predetermined venue.[72]
words.name: Cup

words.def: Cup run: a series of wins in a cup competition, usually applied to teams from lower division.[73]
words.name: Cup run

words.def: Cup-tied: where a player is ineligible to play in a cup competition because they have played for a different team earlier in the same competition.[74]
words.name: Cup-tied

words.def: Cupset: A modern portmanteau of "cup" and "upset", often used in sports journalism to describe a win for an underdog in a knockout competition.[75][76]
words.name: Cupset

words.def: Curl: see bend.
words.name: Curl

words.def: Curva: curved stands behind the goals in a football stadium, usually home to fanatical fans, or "ultras".[77][78]
words.name: Curva

words.def: Custodian: alternative term for a goalkeeper.[79][80]
words.name: Custodian

words.def: D: semi-circular arc at the edge of the penalty area, used to indicate the portion of the 10-yard distance around the penalty spot that lies outside the penalty area. Referred to in the Laws of the Game as "the penalty arc".[55]
words.name: D

words.def: Dead ball: situation when the game is restarted with the ball stationary, such as a free kick.[81]
words.name: Dead ball

words.def: Deep: used to describe the positioning of a player (or a line of players, such as the defence or midfield) who is playing closer to their own goal than they traditionally would. A defence may drop deep against a team with fast attacking players, to reduce the amount of space behind the defence for fast-paced players to break into.[82] Attacking players who traditionally play deep may be described as being a deep-lying forward or a deep-lying playmaker.
words.name: Deep

words.def: Defender: one of the four main positions in football. Defenders are positioned in front of the goalkeeper and have the principal role of keeping the opposition away from their goal.[30]
words.name: Defender

words.def: Derby: match between two, usually local, rivals.[83]
words.name: Derby

words.def: Designated player rule: rule in Major League Soccer that allows teams to nominate players who are paid either partially or completely outside the salary cap.[84]
words.name: Designated player rule

words.def: Direct free kick: awarded to fouled team following certain listed "penal" fouls.[85] A goal may be scored directly from a direct free kick.
words.name: Direct free kick

words.def: Dirty work: the type of play undertaken by a defensive midfielder – such as making tackles in midfield, playing short passes to the wing, and breaking up opponents' attacking moves – which is necessary for a team to be successful, but rarely receives recognition or acclaim, and is not considered "glamorous".[86]
words.name: Dirty work

words.def: Dissent: breach of the Laws of the Game, whereby a player uses offensive language or gestures towards official(s). In extreme cases it can result in yellow or red cards being issued.[87]
words.name: Dissent

words.def: Diving: form of cheating, sometimes employed by an attacking player to win a free kick or penalty.[81] When being challenged for the ball by an opponent, the player will throw themselves to the ground as though they had been fouled, in an attempt to deceive the referee into thinking a foul has been committed.[88] Also known as a flop.
words.name: Diving

words.def: Doing a Leeds: when a club incurs substantial debts through over-ambitious spending and subsequently drops down one or more divisions. Named after Leeds United, who reached the semi-finals of the UEFA Champions League in 2001 as a Premier League club but were playing in Football League One only six years later.[89] The phrase is sometimes also used in relation to other clubs, for instance "Doing a Wimbledon".[90]
words.name: Doing a Leeds

words.def: Double: most commonly used when a club wins both its domestic league and its country's major cup competition in the same season.[81] Also used to describe a pair of victories, home and away, by one club over another in the same league season.[91]
words.name: Double

words.def: Dribbling: when a player runs with the ball at their feet under close control. Dribbling on a winding course past several opponents in close proximity without losing possession is sometimes described as making a mazy run or mazy dribble.[81][92]
words.name: Dribbling

words.def: Drop ball: method used to restart a game, sometimes when a player has been injured accidentally and the game is stopped while the ball is still in play.[93]
words.name: Drop ball

words.def: Dugout: see bench.
words.name: Dugout

words.def: Dummy: skill move performed by a player receiving a pass from a teammate; the player receiving the ball will angle their body in such a way that the opponent thinks they are going to play the ball. The player will then intentionally allow the ball to run by them to a teammate close by without touching it, confusing the opponent as to which player has the ball.[94]
words.name: Dummy

words.def: El Clásico: derby fixtures in Spanish-speaking countries such as Argentina[95] and Mexico.[96] In Spain, and countries where Spanish is not a primary language, it is commonly understood as the name of the derby between Spanish clubs Real Madrid and Barcelona.[97]
words.name: El Clásico

words.def: Elevator team: see Yo-yo club.
words.name: Elevator team

words.def: Equaliser: goal that makes the score even.[30]
words.name: Equaliser

words.def: European night: night-time game in a UEFA club competition.[98]
words.name: European night

words.def: Exhibition match: see Friendly.
words.name: Exhibition match

words.def: Extra time: additional period, normally two halves of 15 minutes, used to determine the winner in some tied cup matches.[30]
words.name: Extra time

words.def: FA Cup: English knockout competition – the oldest cup tournament in the world.[99]
words.name: FA Cup

words.def: False nine: A centre forward who regularly drops back into midfield to disrupt opposition marking.[100]
words.name: False nine

words.def: Fan: follower of a football team or someone who simply enjoys watching the game. Also known as supporter.[101]
words.name: Fan

words.def: Fan park: area away from grounds – often in city centres – used to screen matches on large television screens for fans, normally for big tournaments such as the World Cup or other important matches.[102]
words.name: Fan park

words.def: Fans' favourite: player that is extremely popular with fans of a club or nation.[103]
words.name: Fans' favourite

words.def: Favourite: team that is expected to win a particular match or tournament.[104] Opposite of underdog.
words.name: Favourite

words.def: FC: initialism for football club, used by teams such as Watford FC.[105]
words.name: FC

words.def: Feeder club: club whose role is to provide first-team experience for younger players with a formal or informal agreement that successful ones can move on to the bigger club.[106]
words.name: Feeder club

words.def: Feign injury: see play-acting
words.name: Feign injury

words.def: Fergie time: the idea that Manchester United, when managed by Sir Alex Ferguson ("Fergie"), got what rival fans considered to be generous and/or excessive added time when Ferguson's team were losing, particularly at home.[107]
words.name: Fergie time

words.def: Field of play: see pitch.
words.name: Field of play

words.def: FIFA: acronym for Fédération Internationale de Football Association (International Federation of Association Football), the world governing body of the sport; pronounced "fee-fa".[108]
words.name: FIFA

words.def: Fifty-fifty: a challenge in which two players have an equal chance of winning control of a loose ball.[109]
words.name: Fifty-fifty

words.def: Final whistle: see full-time.
words.name: Final whistle

words.def: First eleven: the eleven players who, when available, would be the ones usually chosen by the team's manager to start a game.[110]
words.name: First eleven

words.def: First team: the most senior team fielded by a club.[111]
words.name: First team

words.def: First touch: skill attribute for a player which signifies their ability to bring the ball completely under control immediately upon receiving it.[112]
words.name: First touch

words.def: Flag: small rectangular flag attached to a handle, used by an assistant referee to signal that they have seen a foul or other infraction take place. One assistant referee's flag is a solid colour (often yellow), and their colleague's has a two-colour (often red and yellow) quartered pattern. Some flags have buttons on the handle, which will activate an alarm worn by the referee to attract their attention. Can also refer to the corner flag.[113] The action of an assistant referee signalling with the flag is called flagging.[114]
words.name: Flag

words.def: Fixture: scheduled match which has yet to be played.[115]
words.name: Fixture

words.def: Flat back four: defensive positioning system, in which the primary first position of each member of a four-man defense is in a straight line across the pitch; often used in conjunction with an offside trap. In formations with three centre backs, the phrase "flat back three" is sometimes used.[116]
words.name: Flat back four

words.def: Flick-on: when a player receives a pass from a teammate and, instead of controlling it, touches the ball with their head or foot while it is moving past them, with the intent of helping the ball reach another teammate.[117]
words.name: Flick-on

words.def: Football: a widely used name for association football.[118] Can also refer to the ball.
words.name: Football

words.def: Football League: English league competition founded in 1888, the oldest such competition in the world.[119]
words.name: Football League

words.def: Football programme: also known as match programme; booklet purchased by spectators prior to a football match containing information relevant to it, including lists of players, short articles penned by commentators and the like. Older programmes may have considerable value as collectables.[120]
words.name: Football programme

words.def: Football pyramid: also known as league system; hierarchy of leagues which teams can be promoted or relegated between, depending on finishing positions or playoffs. They are often referred to as "pyramids" due to their tendency to have increasing number of divisions further down the tiers (or "steps"), leading to a pyramid-like structure.[121]
words.name: Football pyramid

words.def: Formation: how the players in a team are positioned on the pitch. The formation is often denoted numerically, with the numbers referring to the corresponding number of players in defensive, midfield and attacking positions.[122]
words.name: Formation

words.def: Forward: see Striker.
words.name: Forward

words.def: Fourth official: additional assistant referee, who has various duties and can replace one of the other officials, in case of injury.[123]
words.name: Fourth official

words.def: Fox in the box: see Goal poacher.
words.name: Fox in the box

words.def: Foul: breach of the Laws of the Game by a player, punishable by a free kick or penalty. Such acts can lead to yellow or red cards depending on their severity.[81]
words.name: Foul

words.def: Free kick: the result of a foul outside the penalty area, given against the offending team. Free kicks can be either direct (shot straight towards the goal) or indirect (the ball must touch another player before a goal can be scored).[81]
words.name: Free kick

words.def: Freestyle football: art of a player expressing themself with a football, while performing various tricks with any part of their body. Similar in style to keepie-uppie and kemari, it has become a widespread sport across the world and is practised by many people.[124]
words.name: Freestyle football

words.def: Friendly: match arranged by two teams with no competitive value, such as a player's testimonial or a warm-up match before a season begins.[81]
words.name: Friendly

words.def: Fullback: position on either side of the defence, whose job is to try to prevent the opposing team attacking down the wings. Also spelt full back or full-back.[125]
words.name: Fullback

words.def: Full-time: either (1) the end of the game, signalled by the referees whistle (also known as the final whistle), (2) a professional footballer or club i.e. their only profession or (3) a word used to describe a permanent coach.[126]
words.name: Full-time

words.def: Futsal: variant of association football that is played on a smaller hard court surface and mainly played indoors.[127] Involves two teams with five players each, one of whom is the goalkeeper, with an unlimited number of substitutes permitted and is played in two periods each lasting 20 minutes.[127] Similar, but not identical, to six-a-side football.
words.name: Futsal

words.def: Game of two halves: expression used by commentators to describe a close match where one team dominates each half.[30]
words.name: Game of two halves

words.def: Game 39: proposal to play an extra round of Premier League matches played outside of the United Kingdom.[128] Also known as the 39th game. Named as such because, since the Premier League is played by 20 teams, and the competition system is the double round-robin (see round-robin tournament), each team plays 38 games in a season.
words.name: Game 39

words.def: Ghost game: a betting scam, first discovered in the early 2010s, in which bookmakers, either by being deceived or as accessories, post odds and take bets on a match that never actually takes place.[129][130]
words.name: Ghost game

words.def: Ghost goal: situations where a ball fairly crossed the goal line but did not result in a goal, or a goal was awarded despite the ball not crossing the line.[131][132]
words.name: Ghost goal

words.def: Giant-killing: cliché used to describe a lower division team defeating another team from a much higher division in that country's league.[133][134]
words.name: Giant-killing

words.def: Give-and-go: see One-two.
words.name: Give-and-go

words.def: Goal: the only method of scoring in football; for a goal to be awarded the ball must pass completely over the goal line in the area between the posts and beneath the crossbar.[93]
words.name: Goal

words.def: Goal average: number of goals scored divided by number of goals conceded. Used as a tie-breaking method before the introduction of goal difference.[135]
words.name: Goal average

words.def: Goal difference: net difference between goals scored and goals conceded.[30] Used to differentiate league positions when clubs are tied on points.[136]
words.name: Goal difference

words.def: Goal hanger: A somewhat disparaging term for a striker who is perceived to spend most of the match in or near the opposing penalty area, waiting for an opportunity to score a goal. Gary Lineker and Filippo Inzaghi are two players who have been described as such.[137][138]
words.name: Goal hanger

words.def: Goalkeeper: player closest to the goal a team is defending. A goalkeeper has the job of preventing the opposition from scoring. They are the only player on the pitch that can handle the ball in open play, although they can only do so in the penalty area.[30] Known informally as a keeper or a goalie.
words.name: Goalkeeper

words.def: Goal kick: method of restarting play when the ball is played over the goal line by a player of the attacking team without a goal being scored.[30]
words.name: Goal kick

words.def: Goal line: line at one of the shorter ends of the pitch, spanning from one corner flag to another, with the goalposts situated at the halfway point; sometimes used to refer to the particular section of the goal line between the two goalposts[139] Also spelt goal-line.
words.name: Goal line

words.def: Goal-line clearance: when a player performs a clearance of the ball right off the goal line.[140]
words.name: Goal-line clearance

words.def: Goal-line technology: a system to determine whether the ball has crossed the line for a goal or not.
words.name: Goal-line technology

words.def: Goal poacher: type of striker, primarily known for excellent scoring ability and movement inside the penalty area.[141]
words.name: Goal poacher

words.def: Goalmouth: the section of the pitch immediately in front of the goal.[142]
words.name: Goalmouth

words.def: Goalmouth scramble: when multiple players from both teams attempt to gain control of a loose ball in the goalmouth. This often results in a short period of chaotic play involving attackers shooting towards goal and defenders blocking shots, balls ricocheting around the goalmouth, and players falling over.[143] Also known as a scrimmage.[144]
words.name: Goalmouth scramble

words.def: Goal of the century: usually used to refer to Diego Maradona's second goal against England in the 1986 FIFA World Cup.[8]
words.name: Goal of the century

words.def: Goalpost: vertical bars at either side of the goal.[145]
words.name: Goalpost

words.def: Goalside: when a player is located closer to the goal than his opponent.
words.name: Goalside

words.def: Golden Generation: an exceptionally talented set of players who are expected to achieve a high level of success,[146] or who have been part of a highly successful squad in a team's history.
words.name: Golden Generation

words.def: Golden goal: method of determining the winner of a match which is a draw after 90 minutes of play. Up to an additional 30 minutes are played in two 15-minute halves, the first team to score wins and the match ends immediately.[147] See also Silver goal.
words.name: Golden goal

words.def: Grand Slam: achieved by a club that wins all official international competitions.[148]
words.name: Grand Slam

words.def: Green card: a virtual card awarded after the game by the referee in Italy's Serie B to a player whose actions illustrate "positive behaviour" during the game.[149]
words.name: Green card

words.def: Groundhopping: hobby among fans, in which the objective is to visit as many football stadiums and grounds as possible. Participants are known as groundhoppers or simply hoppers.[150]
words.name: Groundhopping

words.def: Group of death: group in a cup competition which is unusually competitive, because the number of strong teams in the group is greater than the number of qualifying places available for the next phase of the tournament.[151]
words.name: Group of death

words.def: Half-back: position employed in a 2–3–5 formation, half-backs would play in front of the full-backs and behind the forwards. The middle half-back was known as a centre-half; those on either side were known as wing-halves.[152]
words.name: Half-back

words.def: Half-time: break between the two halves of a match, usually lasts 15 minutes.[153]
words.name: Half-time

words.def: Half-volley: pass or shot in which the ball is struck just as, or just after, it touches the ground.[118]
words.name: Half-volley

words.def: Handbags: colloquialism, especially in the United Kingdom, used to describe an event where two or more players from opposing teams square up to each other in a threatening manner, or push and jostle each other in an attempt to assert themselves, without any actual violent conduct taking place.[79]
words.name: Handbags

words.def: Handball or handball: when a player (other than a goalkeeper inside their penalty area) deliberately touches the ball with their hand in active play. A foul is given against the player if spotted.[154]
words.name: Handball or handball

words.def: Hand of God: Diego Maradona's first goal against England in the 1986 FIFA World Cup, which he scored by using his hand.[155]
words.name: Hand of God

words.def: Hat-trick: when a player scores three goals in a single match.[156]
words.name: Hat-trick

words.def: Header: using the head as a means of playing or controlling the ball.[118]
words.name: Header

words.def: High foot: colloquialism for what is described in the Laws of the Game as "Playing in a dangerous manner".[157] A foul is awarded if the referee determines that a player's foot has moved into a dangerously high position while trying to play the ball, especially if the foot threatens or causes an injury to an opponent.[158]
words.name: High foot

words.def: Holding role or Holding midfielder: central midfielder whose primary role is to protect the defence.[159]
words.name: Holding role

words.def: Hold up the ball: when a player, usually a forward, receives a long ball from a teammate, and controls and shields it from the opposition, with the intent of slowing the play down to allow teammates to join the attack.[160]
words.name: Hold up the ball

words.def: Hole: space on a pitch between the midfield and forwards. In formations where attacking midfielders or deep-lying forwards are used, they are said to be "playing in the hole".[79]
words.name: Hole

words.def: Hollywood ball: a spectacular-looking long range pass, but one which rarely achieves what the passer hopes.[161]
words.name: Hollywood ball

words.def: Home and away: a team's own ground and their opponent's, respectively. The team playing at their own stadium is said to have "home advantage."[162][163]
words.name: Home and away

words.def: Hooligans: fanatical supporters known for violence.[164]
words.name: Hooligans

words.def: Hospital ball: sometimes referred to as hospital pass; when a player plays a slightly under-strength pass to a teammate, to such an extent that it becomes likely that both the teammate and an opposing player will come into contact with the ball simultaneously, therefore increasing the likelihood of one or both players suffering an injury while challenging for the ball.[165]
words.name: Hospital ball

words.def: Howler: glaring and possibly amusing error made by a player or referee during a match.[166]
words.name: Howler

words.def: Humdinger: Used to describe a highly anticipated or thrilling match.[167]
words.name: Humdinger

words.def: IFAB: initialism for the International Football Association Board, the body that determines the Laws of the Game of association football.[168]
words.name: IFAB

words.def: Indirect free kick: type of free kick awarded to the opposing team following "non-penal" fouls, certain technical infringements, or when play is stopped to caution or dismiss an opponent without a specific foul having occurred. Unlike in a direct free kick, a goal may not be scored directly from an indirect free kick.[169]
words.name: Indirect free kick

words.def: Indoor football: see six-a-side football.
words.name: Indoor football

words.def: Indoor soccer: see six-a-side football.
words.name: Indoor soccer

words.def: Injury time: see stoppage time.
words.name: Injury time

words.def: Inside forward: position employed in a 2–3–5 formation. The inside forwards played just behind the centre forward, similar to the modern attacking midfielder or second striker.[170]
words.name: Inside forward

words.def: Intercept: to prevent a pass from reaching its intended recipient.[171]
words.name: Intercept

words.def: International break: period of time set aside by FIFA for scheduled international matches per their International Match Calendar. Also known as FIFA International Day/Date(s).[172]
words.name: International break

words.def: International clearance: clearance required from foreign or overseas football associations before the transfer of a player can be completed where that player is moving across national or international borders.[173]
words.name: International clearance

words.def: Jew goal: term used to describe a goal scored when a player "passes the ball when two-on-one with the keeper in order to provide the receiver with an open goal".[174] The term is antisemitic, indicates a goal scored unfairly and plays on the stereotype of Jews as cheap.[175][176]
words.name: Jew goal

words.def: Journeyman: player who has represented many different clubs over their career.[177] Opposite of one-club man.
words.name: Journeyman

words.def: Jumpers for goalposts: informal name for a version of street football where players lay down items of clothing to mark out the two goals.[178] The term also has a nostalgia factor, especially in England, intended to invoke memories of a more "innocent" and "pure" type of football from previous generations.[179]
words.name: Jumpers for goalposts

words.def: Keeper: see goalkeeper.
words.name: Keeper

words.def: Keepie-uppie: the skill of juggling a football, keeping it off the ground using the feet, the knees, the chest, the shoulders or the head.[180] Also known as keepy-uppy or kick-ups. The phrases are sometimes spelt as two separate words, for instance keepie uppie.
words.name: Keepie-uppie

words.def: Kick and rush: style of play.[181] See also Long ball.
words.name: Kick and rush

words.def: Kick-off: method of starting a match; the ball must be played forwards from the centre spot with all members of the opposing team at least 10 yards from the ball.[182] Also used to restart the match when a goal has been scored.[182]
words.name: Kick-off

words.def: Kit: football-specific clothing worn by players, consisting at the minimum of a shirt, shorts, socks, specialised footwear, and (for goalkeepers) specialised gloves.[183] Also known as a uniform or a strip.
words.name: Kit

words.def: Kop: British colloquial name for terraced stands in stadiums, especially those immediately behind the goals. Most commonly associated with Liverpool F.C., they are so named due to their steep nature, which resembles a hill in South Africa that was the scene of the Battle of Spion Kop in January 1900 during the Second Boer War.[184]
words.name: Kop

words.def: Last man: situation where an attacking player is in possession, with only one opposing defender between the ball and the goal. If the defender commits a foul on the attacker, a red card is usually shown.[185]
words.name: Last man

words.def: Lay-off pass: short pass, usually lateral, played delicately into the space immediately in front of a teammate who is arriving at speed from behind the player making the pass; the player receiving the pass will then be able to take control of the ball without breaking stride, or (if they are close enough to the goal) attempt to score with a first-time shot.[186]
words.name: Lay-off pass

words.def: Laws of the Game: codified rules that help define association football. These laws are published by the sport's governing body FIFA, with the approval of the International Football Association Board, the body that writes and maintains the laws. The laws mention: the number of players a team should have, the game length, the size of the field and ball, the type and nature of fouls that referees may penalise, the frequently misinterpreted offside law, and many other laws that define the sport.[187]
words.name: Laws of the Game

words.def: League: form of competition in which clubs are ranked by the number of points they accumulate over a series of matches.[188] Often structured as round-robin tournaments.
words.name: League

words.def: Libero: see Sweeper.
words.name: Libero

words.def: Linesman: see Assistant referee.
words.name: Linesman

words.def: Loan: when a player temporarily plays for a club other than the one they are currently contracted to. Such a loan may last from a few weeks to one or more seasons. This often occurs with young players who are commonly loaned to lower league clubs in order to gain valuable experience. The loaning club often takes over the responsibility of paying the player's wages so it can also occur when the originating club seeks to cut down expenses.[189]
words.name: Loan

words.def: Long ball: attempt to distribute the ball a long distance down the field via a cross, without the intention to pass it to the feet of the receiving player. Often used to speed up play, the technique can be especially effective for a team with either fast or tall strikers.[190]
words.name: Long ball

words.def: Lost the dressing room: where a team's manager is deemed to have lost control and support of the players.[191]
words.name: Lost the dressing room

words.def: Magic sponge: sponge filled with water which has a seemingly miraculously reviving effect on injured players.[192]
words.name: Magic sponge

words.def: Manager: the individual in charge of the day-to-day running of the team. Duties of the manager usually include overseeing training sessions, designing tactical plays, choosing the team's formation, picking the starting eleven, and making tactical switches and substitutions during games. Some managers also take on backroom administrative responsibilities such as signing players, negotiating player contracts. Sometimes these tasks are also undertaken by a two separate individuals: a Head coach for on-field tasks, and a General manager or Director of Football for off-field administrative duties.[193]
words.name: Manager

words.def: Man of the match: award, often decided by pundits or sponsors, given to the best player in a game.[194][195]
words.name: Man of the match

words.def: Man on!: warning shout uttered by players (and fans) to a teammate with the ball to alert him of the presence of an opposing player behind him.[30]
words.name: Man on!

words.def: Man-to-man marking: system of marking in which each player is responsible for an opposing player rather than an area of the pitch. Compare with zonal marking.[196]
words.name: Man-to-man marking

words.def: Marking: Defensive strategy, aimed at preventing an attacker from receiving the ball from a teammate. See man-to-man marking and zonal marking.
words.name: Marking

words.def: Match fixing: expression used to describe the situation when a match is played to a completely or partially pre-determined result motivated by financial incentives paid to players, team officials or referees in violation of the rules of the game.[197]
words.name: Match fixing

words.def: Mazy run: see Dribbling.
words.name: Mazy run

words.def: Medical: mandatory procedure undertaken by a player prior to signing for a new team which assesses the player's fitness and overall medical health. Usually the procedure includes muscle and ligament/joint examinations, cardiovascular tests to identify potential heart problems, respiratory tests, and neurological tests to identify possible concussions or other such problems.[198][199]
words.name: Medical

words.def: Mexican wave: self-organised crowd activity in which spectators stand up, raise their hands in the air, and sit down in sequence, creating a ripple effect that moves around the stadium's stands. Despite having been carried out in stadia for many years previously, it was first brought to world-wide attention during the 1986 FIFA World Cup in Mexico, hence its name.[200][201]
words.name: Mexican wave

words.def: Mickey Mouse cup: cup, league, or other competition considered of a lower standard, importance, or significance.[202]
words.name: Mickey Mouse cup

words.def: Midfielder: one of the four main positions in football. Midfielders are positioned between the defenders and strikers.[203]
words.name: Midfielder

words.def: Minnow: see underdog.[204]
words.name: Minnow

words.def: Multiball system: the use of several balls during a game, intended to reduce the amount of time the ball is not in play. Historically, the same ball was used throughout the entire game, and had to be retrieved every time it went out of play. Under the multiball system, as soon as the ball goes out of play, a new ball is passed to the player by a ball boy, who then retrieves the other ball while the game continues.[205]
words.name: Multiball system

words.def: Near post/Far post: notional concept, referring to the position of a goalkeeper in relation to the posts.[118] When an attacker scores a goal by placing the ball between the goalkeeper and the post to which they are closest, the goalkeeper is said to have been beaten at the near post.[206]
words.name: Near post/Far post

words.def: Neutral ground: venue for a match that belongs to neither team.[207]
words.name: Neutral ground

words.def: Nutmeg: when a player intentionally plays the ball between an opponent's legs, runs past the opponent, and collects their own pass.[79]
words.name: Nutmeg

words.def: Obstruction: illegal defensive technique, in which a defensive player who does not have control of the ball positions their body between the ball and an attacking opponent, or otherwise blocks or checks an opponent, in order to prevent that opponent from reaching the ball.[169] When the defensive player has control of the ball, this technique is known as shielding, and is permitted under the laws of the game.[208]
words.name: Obstruction

words.def: OFC: initialism for the Oceania Football Confederation, the governing body of the sport in Oceania.[20]
words.name: OFC

words.def: Offside: Law 11 of the laws of football, relating to the positioning of defending players in relation to attacking players when the ball is played to an attacking player by a teammate. In its most basic form, a player is offside if they are in their opponent's half of the field, and is closer to the goal line than both the second-last defender and the ball at the moment the ball is played to them by a teammate.[209]
words.name: Offside

words.def: Offside trap: defensive tactical maneuver, in which each member of a team's defense will simultaneously step forward as the ball is played forward to an opponent, in an attempt to put that opponent in an offside position.[210] An unsuccessful performance of this maneuver results in the opponent "beating the offside trap".[211]
words.name: Offside trap

words.def: Olympic goal: goal scored directly from a corner kick.[212]
words.name: Olympic goal

words.def: One touch: style of play in which the ball is passed around quickly using just one touch. Also used for the same type of training which aims to improve the speed of players' reaction when receiving the ball.[213] See also Tiki-taka.
words.name: One touch

words.def: One-club man: player who spends their entire professional career at one club.[214] Opposite of journeyman.
words.name: One-club man

words.def: One-on-one: situation where the only player between an attacking player and the goal is the opponent's goalkeeper.[215]
words.name: One-on-one

words.def: One-two: skill move between team mates to move the ball past an opponent. Player One passes the ball to Player Two and runs past the opponent, whereupon they immediately receive the ball back from Player Two, who has received, controlled, and passed the ball in one movement.[210] Also known as a give-and-go.[216]
words.name: One-two

words.def: Open goal: where no player is defending the goal.[217]
words.name: Open goal

words.def: Opportunity: see chance.
words.name: Opportunity

words.def: Outfield player: any player other than the goalkeeper.[210]
words.name: Outfield player

words.def: Outside forward: position used in a 2–3–5 formation, in which they are the main attacking threat from the flanks. Similar to modern wingers.[218]
words.name: Outside forward

words.def: Overhead kick: see Bicycle kick.
words.name: Overhead kick

words.def: Overlap: move between teammates. An attacking player (who has the ball) is shadowed by a single defender; the attacker's teammate runs past both players, forcing the defender to either continue to shadow the player on the ball, or attempt to prevent the teammate from receiving a pass. The first player can either pass the ball or keep possession, depending on which decision the defender makes.[219]
words.name: Overlap

words.def: Own goal: where a player scores a goal against their own team, usually as the result of an error.[210][220]
words.name: Own goal

words.def: Panenka: skill move used when taking a penalty kick wherein the player taking the penalty delicately chips the ball over a diving goalkeeper, rather than striking the ball firmly, as is the norm. Named after Antonín Panenka, who famously scored such a penalty for Czechoslovakia against West Germany in the final of the 1976 UEFA European Football Championship.[221]
words.name: Panenka

words.def: Parachute payment: series of payments made for four years by the Premier League to every club relegated from that league.[222]
words.name: Parachute payment

words.def: Paralympic football: consists of adaptations of the sport of association football for athletes with a disability.[223] These sports are typically played using FIFA rules, with modifications to the field of play, equipment, numbers of players, and other rules as required to make the game suitable for the athletes. The two most prominent versions of Paralympic football are Football 5-a-side, for athletes with visual impairments, and Football 7-a-side, for athletes with cerebral palsy.[224]
words.name: Paralympic football

words.def: Parking the bus: expression used when all the players on a team play defensively, usually when the team is intending to draw the game or defending a narrow margin. The term was coined by Chelsea F.C. manager Jose Mourinho, referring to Tottenham Hotspur F.C. during a game against Chelsea in 2004.[225] See also Catenaccio.
words.name: Parking the bus

words.def: Pass: when a player kicks the ball to one of their teammates.[30][210]
words.name: Pass

words.def: Passive offside: exception to the offside rule, wherein play may continue if a player in an offside position makes no attempt to involve himself in the game at the moment an offside call would usually be made, and allows an onside player to win control of the ball instead.[226]
words.name: Passive offside

words.def: Penalty area: rectangular area measuring 44 yards (40.2 metres) by 18 yards (16.5 metres) in front of each goal.[227]
words.name: Penalty area

words.def: Penalty kick: kick taken 12 yards (11 metres) from goal, awarded when a team commits a foul inside its own penalty area, and the infringement would usually be punishable by a direct free kick.[228]
words.name: Penalty kick

words.def: Penalty shootout: method of deciding a match in a knockout competition, which has ended in a draw after full-time and extra-time. Players from each side take it in turns to attempt to score a penalty against the opposition goalkeeper. Sudden death is introduced if scores are level after five penalties have been taken by either side. Also spelt penalty shoot-out.[30]
words.name: Penalty shootout

words.def: Perfect hat-trick: when a player scores three goals in a single match, one with the left foot, one with the right foot and one with a header.[229]
words.name: Perfect hat-trick

words.def: Phantom goal: see Ghost goal.
words.name: Phantom goal

words.def: Phoenix club: club which has been created following the demise of a pre-existing club. Phoenix clubs usually take on the same colours and fan base as those of the defunct club and may even be established by fans themselves.[230]
words.name: Phoenix club

words.def: Pitch: playing surface for a game of football; usually a specially prepared grass field. Referred to in the Laws of the Game as the field of play.[55]
words.name: Pitch

words.def: Pitch invasion: when a crowd of people who are watching run onto the pitch to celebrate, protest about an incident or confront opposition fans. Known as rushing the field in the United States.[231][232]
words.name: Pitch invasion

words.def: Play-acting: similar to diving, play-acting is deceiving the officials that a player is injured to try to gain an advantage or force the referee to punish the "aggressor". Also known as feigning injury or Diving.[233]
words.name: Play-acting

words.def: Play to the whistle: an informal phrase used to instruct players to keep on playing until the referee blows their whistle.[234]
words.name: Play to the whistle

words.def: Playing advantage: see advantage.
words.name: Playing advantage

words.def: Playmaker: attacking player whose job is to control the flow of their team's play.[235]
words.name: Playmaker

words.def: Playoff: series of matches towards the end of the season that determine clubs which are promoted and/or relegated, determine tied league positions or determine qualifiers for continental competitions.[30][210] In some leagues, playoffs are also used to determine that season's champions.[citation needed]
words.name: Playoff

words.def: Points deduction: method of punishing clubs for breaching the rules of a tournament by reducing the number of accumulated points during a league season. Points deductions can be applied for offences such as going into administration,[236] financial irregularities,[237] fielding ineligible players,[238] match fixing,[239] or violent conduct amongst club staff or supporters.[240]
words.name: Points deduction

words.def: Post: see goalpost.
words.name: Post

words.def: The Poznań: celebration which involves fans turning their backs to the pitch, joining arms and jumping up and down in unison. It takes its name from Polish club Lech Poznań, whose fans are thought to be the first to celebrate in this way.[241]
words.name: The Poznań

words.def: Pre-season: period leading up to the start of a league season. Clubs generally prepare for a new season with intensive training, playing various friendlies, and sometimes by attempting to sign new players.[242][243]
words.name: Pre-season

words.def: Premier League: name of the top division of English football since 1992.[244] The phrase can also be used generically, or as a translation for leagues in other countries.[245][246]
words.name: Premier League

words.def: Pressing: A tactic where defending players move forward towards the ball, rather than remaining in position near their goal. They may pressure the player that has the ball or get close to other opponents in order to remove passing options. A successful press will recover the ball quickly and further up the pitch, or force the opponents to make an inaccurate long kick. However, if the opponents are able to pass the ball forward, fewer defending players are protecting the goal, making pressing a high-risk, high-reward strategy.[247][248]
words.name: Pressing

words.def: Professional: player who is engaged by a club under a professional contract and who is paid a wage by the club to focus on their sport in lieu of other employment.[249]
words.name: Professional

words.def: Professional foul: foul committed by a player who is aware that they are about to intentionally commit the foul, and who does so having calculated the risk, and determined that committing the foul and taking a yellow card or even a red card will be more beneficial to their team than if the player allowed their opponent to continue unimpeded.[210]
words.name: Professional foul

words.def: Promedios: relegation system based on a points per game average over multiple seasons.[250]
words.name: Promedios

words.def: Promotion: when a club moves up to a higher division in the league hierarchy as a result of being one of the best teams in their division at the end of a season.[210]
words.name: Promotion

words.def: Pyramid: may refer to the 2–3–5 formation, or to a football pyramid, a hierarchical structure of leagues.
words.name: Pyramid

words.def: Rabona: method of kicking the football whereby the kicking leg is wrapped around the back of the standing leg.[251]
words.name: Rabona

words.def: Red card: awarded to a player for either a single serious cautionable offence or following two yellow cards.[210] The player receiving the red card is compelled to leave the game for the rest of its duration, and that player's team is not allowed to replace him with another player. A player receiving the red card is said to have been sent off or ejected.[252]
words.name: Red card

words.def: Reducer: hard tackle, usually early in a game, meant to intimidate an attacking player.[253]
words.name: Reducer

words.def: Referee: the official who presides over a match, with the help of assistant referees and the fourth official.[210]
words.name: Referee

words.def: Replacement: see substitute
words.name: Replacement

words.def: Relegation: when a club moves down to a lower division in the league hierarchy as a result of gaining the least number of points in their division at the end of a season.[254]
words.name: Relegation

words.def: Reserve team: team which is considered supplemental to the club's senior team. Matches between reserve teams often include a combination of first team players that have not featured in recent games, as well as academy and trial players.[255]
words.name: Reserve team

words.def: Retired number: squad number which is no longer used as a form of recognising an individual player's loyal service to the club. Sometimes a number is retired as a memorial after their death.[256][257]
words.name: Retired number

words.def: Ronglish: phrases associated used by manager and pundit Ron Atkinson to describe action during a match. Expressions used by Atkinson include similes and verbal non sequiturs.[258]
words.name: Ronglish

words.def: Round-robin tournament: competition in which each contestant meets all other contestants in turn.[259] A competition where each team plays the other teams twice is known as a double round-robin.[260]
words.name: Round-robin tournament

words.def: Rounding the 'keeper: attacking move in which a player attempts to dribble the ball around the goalkeeper, hoping to leave an open goal.[261]
words.name: Rounding the 'keeper

words.def: Route one: direct, attacking style of football which generally involves taking the most direct route to goal.[262]
words.name: Route one

words.def: Roy of the Rovers stuff: event during a game, or an entire game, in which a player or team is seen to have overcome some sort of extreme adversity prior to victory, or secured victory in an overtly spectacular or dramatic fashion, especially against a team generally considered to be "stronger".[263] The term originates from the long-running football-themed English comic strip Roy of the Rovers, in which such events were commonplace.[264]
words.name: Roy of the Rovers stuff

words.def: Row Z: cliché used by commentators to describe the hypothetical destination of a forceful clearance, on the assumption that rows in which spectators are seated are ordered alphabetically so that row Z is the furthest from the pitch. Also used to describe a shot which goes a long way over the crossbar.[265]
words.name: Row Z

words.def: Safety: see Survive.
words.name: Safety

words.def: Save: when a goalkeeper prevents the football from crossing the goal line between the goalposts.[254]
words.name: Save

words.def: Scissor kick: see Bicycle kick.
words.name: Scissor kick

words.def: Scorpion kick: acrobatic kick of the type first notably performed as a save by René Higuita in 1995 while playing for Colombia at Wembley stadium against England.[266]
words.name: Scorpion kick

words.def: Scrimmage: a term used in the nineteenth century for what would now be called a goalmouth scramble. In the early days of newspaper coverage of the sport, reporters were often unable to identify the scorer of a goal under such circumstances and would report simply that the goal had been scored "from a scrimmage". For this reason, the scorers of several goals in early FA Cup finals are unknown.[267]
words.name: Scrimmage

words.def: Seal dribble: type of dribble, in which a player flicks the ball up from the ground onto their head and then proceeds to run past opponents whilst bouncing the ball on top of their forehead, somewhat imitating a seal.[268]
words.name: Seal dribble

words.def: Season: the time period during which primary competitions in a certain country are played. In most European countries the season starts around September and ends in May, with a winter break in December and January. In other countries the season is played within a single calendar year. It is often customary to use the Super Cup to mark the beginning of a season while the Cup final usually marks its end.
words.name: Season

words.def: Second season syndrome: phrase sometimes used by commentators in English football used to describe a downturn in fortunes for a football club two seasons after its promotion to the Premier League.[269]
words.name: Second season syndrome

words.def: Sending off: see red card.
words.name: Sending off

words.def: Set piece: dead ball routine that the attacking team has specifically practised, such as a free kick taken close to the D.[254]
words.name: Set piece

words.def: Shielding: defensive technique, in which a defensive player positions their body between the ball and an attacking opponent, in order to prevent that opponent from reaching the ball.[118] At all times while shielding the ball, the defender must maintain control of the ball within a nominal playing distance, otherwise the technique becomes obstruction, and a foul is called.[208]
words.name: Shielding

words.def: Shin pads or Shin guards: mandatory piece of equipment, usually made of plastic or rubber, worn underneath the socks in order to protect the shins.[270]
words.name: Shin pads

words.def: Shoot: specialised kicking technique mainly used by forwards. The purpose of shooting is to get the ball past the goal line (usually beating the goalkeeper in the process), though some shots may be made in order to win corners or force the keeper to deflect the ball into the path of a teammate - this will only be the case if scoring directly from the shot seems unlikely. See Shooting (association football). To attempt to shoot is to take a shot.[30][254]
words.name: Shoot

words.def: Shootout: see penalty shootout.
words.name: Shootout

words.def: Shutout: see Clean sheet.
words.name: Shutout

words.def: Side netting: outside of the net part of the goal, which stretches back from the goalpost to the stanchion.[271]
words.name: Side netting

words.def: Silver goal: rule which was briefly in use between 2002 and 2004 in some UEFA competitions when elimination matches were level after 90 minutes. In extra time, the match would end if one team was winning after fifteen minutes of extra time. Unlike the golden goal, the game did not finish the moment a goal was scored.[254]
words.name: Silver goal

words.def: Silverware: a slang term for the trophies teams receive for winning competitions
words.name: Silverware

words.def: Simulation: see diving.
words.name: Simulation

words.def: Six-a-side football: variant of association football adapted for play in an arena such as a turf-covered hockey arena or a skating rink. Unlike in futsal the playing field is surrounded by a wall instead of touch lines. The ball can be played directly off the wall, which eliminates many frequent stoppages that would normally result in throw-ins, goal kicks and corner kicks. Played by two teams with 6 players each.[272] Also known as arena soccer, indoor football, indoor soccer or simply as six-a-side.
words.name: Six-a-side football

words.def: Six-pointer: game between teams both competing for a title, promotion or relegation, whereby the relative difference between winning and losing can be six points.[273]
words.name: Six-pointer

words.def: Slide tackle: type of tackle where the defending player slides along the ground to tackle their opponent.[118]
words.name: Slide tackle

words.def: Soccer: alternative name for the sport of association football. Originating in Britain, and derived from the "s-o-c" in "association", the word was commonly used in the UK until the 1970s.[274] Now it is used most commonly in countries where other codes of football are prominent, for instance American football in the United States,[275] and Australian rules football and rugby league in Australia.[276]
words.name: Soccer

words.def: Spion Kop: see Kop.
words.name: Spion Kop

words.def: Spot-kick: see penalty-kick.
words.name: Spot-kick

words.def: Squad numbers: numerical markings on players' shirts used to distinguish individual players in a game of football. First used in 1928,[277] and initially assigned to distinguish positions in a formation, they gradually became associated with individual players, irrespective of where they are positioned on the pitch.[278] This gave rise to the custom of retiring numbers.[257]
words.name: Squad numbers

words.def: Squad rotation system: managerial device, whereby the manager selects from a large number of players in first team games, rather than having a regular first eleven.[279]
words.name: Squad rotation system

words.def: Square ball: when a ball is passed between teammates laterally, across the field of play.[280]
words.name: Square ball

words.def: Squeaky-bum time: tense final stages of a league competition, especially from the point of view of the title contenders, and clubs facing promotion and relegation.[281] Coined by Manchester United manager Alex Ferguson.[281]
words.name: Squeaky-bum time

words.def: Stanchion: part of the framework of the goal which holds the upper rear part of the net in the air and away from the crossbar.[282]
words.name: Stanchion

words.def: Stepover: skill move performed by an attacking player in which the player with the ball will move their foot over the ball without making contact with it.[254] The intent of the move is to confuse a defender into thinking that the attacking player is moving with the ball in a certain direction; when the defender changes direction, the attacker will quickly change direction. Also spelt step over.[283]
words.name: Stepover

words.def: Stoppage time: an additional number of minutes at the end of each half, determined by the match officials, to compensate for time lost during the game. Informally known by various names, including injury time and added time.[30]
words.name: Stoppage time

words.def: Straight red: a penalty given by the referee in punishment for a serious offence that is deemed to be worse than a booking and results in immediate sending off of a player
words.name: Straight red

words.def: Street football: informal variations of the sport. Games often forgo many requirements of a formal game of football, such as a large field, field markings, goal apparatus and corner flags, eleven players per team, or match officials (referee and assistant referees). Synonymous with jumpers for goalposts.[284]
words.name: Street football

words.def: Striker: one of the four main positions in football. Strikers are the players closest to the opposition goal, with the principal role of scoring goals. Also known as forward or attacker.[30]
words.name: Striker

words.def: Studs: small points on the underneath of a player's boots to help prevent slipping.[285] A tackle in which a player directs their studs towards an opponent is referred to as a studs-up challenge, and is a foul punishable by a red card.[286]
words.name: Studs

words.def: Substitute: a player who is brought on to the pitch during a match in exchange for an existing player.[30]
words.name: Substitute

words.def: Subbed: A player who is withdrawn from the field of play and replaced by a substitute is said to have been subbed or subbed off. An oncoming substitute may be referred to as being subbed on.
words.name: Subbed

words.def: Sudden death: feature of penalty shootouts. If scores are level after each side has taken five penalties, the shootout continues until one side misses.[287]
words.name: Sudden death

words.def: Super Hat-trick: when a player scores four goals in a single match.
words.name: Super Hat-trick

words.def: Supporter: see fan.
words.name: Supporter

words.def: Survive: opposite of Relegation, when a struggling team secures enough points to guarantee their position in that league for the following season. Also known as securing safety.[288]
words.name: Survive

words.def: Suspension: players are forced to miss their team's next game(s) if they pick up an allotted number of bookings in league or tournament matches, or are sent off in a previous fixture.[254]
words.name: Suspension

words.def: Sweeper: defender whose role is to protect the space between the goalkeeper and the rest of the defence. Also referred to as libero.[54]
words.name: Sweeper

words.def: Tackle: method of a player winning the ball back from an opponent, achieved either by using a leg to wrest possession from the opponent, or making a slide tackle to knock the ball away. A tackle in which the opposing player is kicked before the ball is punishable by either a free kick or penalty kick. Dangerous tackles may also result in a yellow or red card.[254] See also reducer.
words.name: Tackle

words.def: (to) Take a touch: to control the ball with a legal part of the body before passing or shooting.
words.name: (to) Take a touch

words.def: (it) Takes a touch: when the ball, often unintentionally, takes a deflection off a player to alter its intended trajectory.
words.name: (it) Takes a touch

words.def: Target man: type of striker.[289] Usually tall, with a strong build and good heading ability, capable of controlling or attacking balls in the air. Target men give the forward line different options in how to attack the goal, and are often used to hold up the ball or play layoff passes to their teammates.[290]
words.name: Target man

words.def: Taylor Report: document written by Lord Taylor concerning the causes and aftermath of the Hillsborough disaster in 1989. Best known for its recommendation that top division stadiums in England and Scotland phase out their terraces and become all-seater.[291]
words.name: Taylor Report

words.def: Technical area: area within which the manager must remain while coaching their team during a match,[292] marked by white lines at the side of the pitch.[254]
words.name: Technical area

words.def: Telstar: match ball designed by Adidas for the 1970 FIFA World Cup. The first ball to use a truncated icosahedron design, with 12 black and 20 white patches intentionally used to improve visibility on black-and-white TV sets.[293] The design remains common in club crests and decorations, even though modern match balls look considerably different. Known as bubamara (ladybug) in countries where Serbo-Croatian is spoken.[294]
words.name: Telstar

words.def: Terrace: standing area of a stadium, consisting of a series of concrete steps which are erected for spectators to stand on. Often occupied by ultras. Terraces have been phased out in some countries, over safety concerns.[295]
words.name: Terrace

words.def: Testimonial match: friendly match organised in honour of a player due to long service, usually 10 years at a single club.[296]
words.name: Testimonial match

words.def: Third man running: when a team is attacking, in addition to the passer and intended receiver of the ball, a player will take part in the movement as an alternative receiver or third man. On completion of the move, the passer will become the third man.[297][298]
words.name: Third man running

words.def: Three points for a win: point system in which three points are awarded to the team winning a match, with no points to the losing team. If the game is drawn, each team receives one point. Replacing the previous convention of two and one points awarded for wins and draws respectively, the system is intended to encourage teams to attack in search of a win, rather than settle for a draw.[299]
words.name: Three points for a win

words.def: Through-ball: pass from the attacking team that goes straight through the opposition's defence to a team-mate. Invariably the team-mate will run onto the ball – standing behind the defenders when the ball was played would result in offside being called.[300]
words.name: Through-ball

words.def: Throw-in: method of restarting play. Involves a player throwing the ball from behind a touchline after it has been kicked out by an opponent.[301]
words.name: Throw-in

words.def: Tifo: originally the Italian word for the phenomenon of supporting a football team, today mainly used for any spectacular choreography displayed by supporters on the terraces of a stadium in connection with an association football match.[302] Primarily arranged by ultras.
words.name: Tifo

words.def: Tiki-taka: style of play characterised by short passing and movement, working the ball through various channels and maintaining possession. The style is primarily associated with Spanish club FC Barcelona and the Spanish national team.[303] See also One touch.
words.name: Tiki-taka

words.def: Toe punt: method of kicking the ball with the tip of the foot. Also known as a toe poke.[304]
words.name: Toe punt

words.def: Too good to go down: belief, often misguided, that the ability within a team will preclude it from relegation.[305]
words.name: Too good to go down

words.def: Top corner: the parts of the goal immediately below the two 90° angles where the crossbar and posts intersect. Generally considered the most difficult part of the goal for a goalkeeper to reach.[306]
words.name: Top corner

words.def: Top flight: the league at the highest level of a league system.[307]
words.name: Top flight

words.def: Total Football: tactical theory in which any outfield player can take over the role of any other player in a team. Invented by the Dutch coach Rinus Michels, Total Football was popularised by AFC Ajax and the Netherlands national team in the early 1970s.[308]
words.name: Total Football

words.def: Touch-line: markings along the side of the pitch, indicating the boundaries of the playing area. Throw-ins are taken from behind this line.[55]
words.name: Touch-line

words.def: Tracksuit manager: phrase used by commentators to describe a manager who has a hands-on approach, meaning that they have a tendency to work with players on the training ground, spending a significant amount of time on improving players' abilities.[309]
words.name: Tracksuit manager

words.def: Transfer window: period during the year in which a football club can transfer players from other countries into their playing staff.[310]
words.name: Transfer window

words.def: Trap: skill performed by a player, whereupon the player uses their foot (or, less commonly, their chest or thigh) to bring an airborne or falling ball under control.[254]
words.name: Trap

words.def: Travelling army: expression used by commentators for any set of away fans – that is, fans who travelled to the match to support their team.[311] Often a team's travelling army are referred to as the 12th man.[312][313]
words.name: Travelling army

words.def: Treble: achieved by a club that wins three major trophies in a single season. Competitions generally considered as part of a treble include the top tier domestic league, domestic cup and continental cup.[314] Trebles achieved without winning a continental competition are known as domestic trebles.[315]
words.name: Treble

words.def: Trialist: player who represents a club on a trial basis, often in the hope of being offered a contract.[317]
words.name: Trialist

words.def: Two-footed tackle: challenge where a player, often a defender, tackles their opponent with both feet. Such tackles often result in a foul being called, if the tackling player is deemed not to be in control of his or her body.[318]
words.name: Two-footed tackle

words.def: UEFA: acronym for Union of European Football Associations, the governing body of the sport in Europe; pronounced "you-eh-fa".[20]
words.name: UEFA

words.def: Underdog: the team that is not expected to win a particular game or competition.[319]
words.name: Underdog

words.def: Under the cosh: a team's defence experiences a period of concerted or unrelenting attacking play.[320]
words.name: Under the cosh

words.def: Ultras: type of football fans predominantly found in Europe renowned for their fanatical support and elaborate displays at football matches. These displays often include the use of flares, vocal support in large groups, displays of banners at stadium terraces and other forms of tifo choreography.[321]
words.name: Ultras

words.def: Upset: game in which the underdog defeats a higher ranked team.[322]
words.name: Upset
