words.def: Utility player: player who can be used in different positions or for different roles transcending the traditional division of outfield players into defenders, midfielders and strikers.[323]
words.name: Utility player

words.def: Vanishing spray: short-lasting aerosol paint applied to the grass by the referee to mark the 10 yard exclusion area at a free kick.[324]
words.name: Vanishing spray

words.def: Video technology: long-campaigned for method of determining close decisions, such as whether a ball crosses the goalline, using instant replays provided by television cameras. It is yet to be introduced by the world governing body FIFA.[325]
words.name: Video technology

words.def: Volley: pass or shot in which the ball is struck before it touches the ground.[79]
words.name: Volley

words.def: Vuvuzela: plastic horn-shaped instruments popularised by supporters at the 2010 FIFA World Cup in South Africa.[326]
words.name: Vuvuzela

words.def: Wall: row of defensive players who line up 10 yards away from a free kick, covering a portion of the goal, with the intent making it more difficult for an attacking player to have a shot on goal direct from the free kick.[79]
words.name: Wall

words.def: Want-away: player who has made public their intentions to leave their current club.[327]
words.name: Want-away

words.def: War chest: the amount of money a manager has been given by a club's chairman, owner or investors to acquire new players.[328]
words.name: War chest

words.def: Webster ruling: 2006 court case which stipulated that players are able to unilaterally walk away from a contract after a fixed period, regardless of the duration of the contract itself. Named after Andy Webster.[329] Compare Bosman ruling.
words.name: Webster ruling

words.def: Wing: area of the pitch that runs parallel to the sidelines.[330]
words.name: Wing

words.def: Winger: wide midfield player whose primary focus is to provide crosses into the penalty area.[79] Alternatively known as a wide midfielder.[330]
words.name: Winger

words.def: Winter break: period between December and January in which competitive football is suspended and which cuts some national or continental seasons in half. Known as "year-end" or "summer break" in the Southern Hemisphere.[331]
words.name: Winter break

words.def: Withdrawn: A forward or attacking midfielder who plays deeper than the name of their conventional position suggests. A forward or attacking midfielder who drops deep may be described as playing in a withdrawn role.[332] Withdrawn may also be used to refer to a player who has been substituted: "the injured midfielder was withdrawn on the hour mark".
words.name: Withdrawn

words.def: Woodwork: common description of the posts and the crossbar, as in "the ball came back off the woodwork", meaning a shot at goal struck either the post or the crossbar and remained in play.[79] The expression is still widely used even though goals are no longer made of wood.[333]
words.name: Woodwork

words.def: Worldy: Used to refer to a goal which is considered to be world class, e.g. "he scored with a worldy".[334] Also used to describe what is considered to be a world-class performance by a player not well known in the game, playing at a lower level.[335]
words.name: Worldy

words.def: Work rate: the extent to which a player contributes to running and chasing in a match while not in possession of the ball.[336] Sometimes spelt workrate or work-rate.[337][338]
words.name: Work rate

words.def: World Cup: Associated with the women's FIFA Women's World Cup,[339] men's FIFA World Cup,[340] international tournaments for youth football, (such as the FIFA U-20 World Cup),[341] and also the FIFA Club World Cup.[342]
words.name: World Cup

words.def: X-rated challenge: malicious tackle when a player has possible motivation to injure an opponent.[343]
words.name: X-rated challenge

words.def: Yellow card: shown by the referee to a player who commits a cautionable offence. If a player commits two cautionable offences in a match, they are shown a second yellow card, followed by a red card, and are then sent off.[344] Also known as a caution or a booking.[30]
words.name: Yellow card

words.def: Youth: a player (or team of players) contracted under the youth system, generally under the age of 18 and not playing professionally although youth players can appear for the first-team.[345][346]
words.name: Youth

words.def: Youth academy: see academy.
words.name: Youth academy

words.def: Yo-yo club: club that is regularly promoted and relegated between higher and lower league levels.[347] Also known in other languages as elevator team, for instance Fahrstuhlmannschaften in German.[348]
words.name: Yo-yo club

words.def: Zonal marking: system of marking, in which each player is responsible for an area of the pitch, rather than an opposing player.[196]
words.name: Zonal marking

words.def: Zona mista: (Italian pronunciation: [ˈdzɔna ˈmista]), tactical theory in which any outfield player can make simultaneously use of defensive individual marking related to catenaccio, the zonal game and continuous attack on the spaces characteristic from total football. The introduction of this system in Italian football has been attributed to Gigi Radice and Giovanni Trapattoni, being popularised by Juventus and the Italian national team in the late 1970s and early 1980s.[349]
words.name: Zona mista
